title: 107_s3105
content: The Act may be cited as the "West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act" and includes a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases, allowing the Secretary to make grants to States for prevention and control efforts. States receiving grants are encouraged to collaborate with local authorities. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director can provide grants to States for West Nile Virus prevention. States are encouraged to work with local health entities for prevention programs. Preference may be given to States with a substantial incidence of the virus or infected mosquitoes. Funds from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention director can be used by States for developing and implementing community-based mosquito control plans for West Nile Virus prevention in areas with high incidence or risk of the virus. The funds allocated for mosquito control plans will be used for developing and evaluating community-based plans and implementing programs on vector-borne diseases to support prevention efforts and training for a competent workforce. The State must provide assurances to the Secretary to receive a grant for developing a competent workforce to manage local mosquito and vector-borne disease control programs. Matching funds and limitations on supplanting are required for eligibility. The State must provide assurances to the Secretary for a grant, ensuring non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs. The State must ensure non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of program costs, which can be in cash or in kind. Federal funds or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in determining non-Federal contributions. The Federal Government cannot be included in determining non-Federal contributions for grants under this subsection. Amounts provided should supplement, not supplant, State and local funds. The Secretary may waive requirements for a State under certain circumstances. The Secretary may waive requirements for a State under certain circumstances, including extraordinary economic conditions. States receiving funds must involve localities in mosquito control plans. The State must involve localities in community-based mosquito control plans and ensure at least 85 percent of the grant is spent locally for public health improvement related to West Nile Virus. Technical assistance is provided with appropriated amounts. Appropriated amounts can be used for technical assistance to expand the CDC's capability in providing support to State and local health departments for mosquito control programs and containment of arboviral diseases. The Secretary provides technical assistance to local health departments for mosquito control programs and arboviral disease containment. Up to 20% of the appropriated amount can be used for this purpose. The Secretary, in consultation with health organizations, will develop guidelines for sustainable mosquito control programs at the state and local levels. The Secretary, in consultation with health organizations, will develop guidelines for sustainable mosquito control programs at the state and local levels. These guidelines will include programs to identify new human cases of disease and track the spread of disease through monitoring infection in various creatures. The guidelines for sustainable mosquito control programs should include identifying new human cases of disease, tracking disease spread through monitoring infection in various creatures, providing laboratory support for testing, increasing participation in surveillance systems, conducting educational outreach campaigns, and outlining procedures for mosquito control. The program established under this subsection includes surveillance for arboviruses, educational outreach campaigns, procedures for mosquito control, and an evaluation conducted by the Secretary. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress 18 months after the enactment of the West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act, including the evaluation results of the program for sustainable mosquito abatement. The report to Congress will include evaluation results of the sustainable mosquito abatement program, progress on guidelines development, and overall program costs and benefits. ARBOVIRUS RESEARCH PROGRAM is added to Part B of title II of the Public Health Service Act. The President is mandated to expand research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, develop rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. The President is required to expand research on controlling insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, developing rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies through various entities including the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences and other Institutes at the National Institutes of Health. Activities under subsection (a) may be carried out through various federal entities such as the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Food and Drug Administration. The President is tasked with promoting coordination between these agencies, the private sector, and experts in public health. The President is responsible for promoting coordination between federal agencies, the private sector, and experts in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 through 2007.
